contextId.information: This is a symbol of shame. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: with your hands on your head

contextId.information: Cutting oneself and shaving one's head were symbolic actions that expressed strong grief, especially when a loved one died. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: No one will cut themselves or shave their heads for them

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of being opposed to a person as if he were to set his face against that person. AT: "I am against you" or "I oppose you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: I have set my face against

contextId.information: These two phrases mean the same thing. The phrase "bowed down" describes the posture that people used in worship. AT: "they worshiped other gods" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: bowed down to other gods and worshiped them

contextId.information: One turns one's face to someone to show that one is listening, and one's back to show that one refuses to listen. AT: "Instead of listening carefully to me, they refused to listen at all" or "They refused to listen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: They turned their backs to me instead of their faces

contextId.information: People tore their cloths when they were extremely sad. AT: "nor did they mourn by tearing their clothes." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: nor did they tear their clothes

contextId.information: These are symbolic actions that show that the men are mourning. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: who had shaved their beard, torn their clothes, and cut themselves

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of being opposed to a person as if he were to set his face against that person. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:21:08|21:10]]. AT: "I will be against you" or "I will oppose you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: I am about to set my face against you
